Pair_Alignment

Jeff Lansing

2025-02-14

Source: vignettes/Pair_Alignment.Rmd
Pair_Alignment.Rmd

Introduction

The goal of this vignette is to use the common expansion of a polyhedron π\pi and its dual δ\delta as a way to align π\pi with δ\delta. (For now we assume without proof that the two expansions are equal. We can see an illustration of this idea for the expansion of the tetrahedron eT and for the expansion of the dual of the tetrahedron edT, at these links).

Aligning the tetrahedron and its dual 

rad <- rhombic_dodecahedron
tet <- tetrahedron
dtet <- dual_tetrahedron
oct <- octahedron
rad$texts <- rep("", 14)
display_poly(rad, dual = oct, 
             scale = 1.5, zoom = 0.65)

Figure 1a. A rhombic dodecahedron
containing an octahedron 

display_poly(rad, dual = tet, codual = dtet, 
             scale = 1.5, zoom = 0.65)

Figure 1b. A rhombic dodecahedron
containing tetrahedra


The octahedron aligns the two tetrahedra in the following sense. Call the vertices where the rhombic dodecahedron intersects the octahedron f-vertices, and where it intersects the tetrahedra t-vertices and s-vertices, respectively. Observe in Figures 1a and 1b above that each f-vertex has 2 t-vertices and 2 s-vertices as neighbors. Then that f-vertex aligns the edge of the tetrahedron between the 2 t-vertices with the edge of the dual tetrahedron between the 2 s-vertices.

We easily get the following alignment table mapping the edges of the tetrahedron to the edges of its dual: $$ \begin{array}{|oct|tet|dual|} \hline f_1 & t_1t_3 & s_2s_4 \\ \hline f_2 & t_2t_4 & s_1s_3 \\ \hline f_3 & t_1t_2 & s_1s_2 \\ \hline f_4 & t_3t_4 & s_3s_4 \\ \hline f_5 & t_2t_3 & s_2s_3 \\ \hline f_6 & t_1t_4 & s_1s_4 \\ \hline \end{array} $$

We can also produce this table autonatically. If we apply the vertex labels to the outer polygon in the order shown, and make a graph of the skeleton of that polygon, then we can manipulate the names of the neighbors of the f-vertices, as follows.

rad$texts <- c(str_c('f',1:6), str_c('s',1:4), str_c('t',1:4))[c(1:6,8,12,11,7,13,9,10,14)]
rad$texts
#>  [1] "f1" "f2" "f3" "f4" "f5" "f6" "s2" "t2" "t1" "s1" "t3" "s3" "s4" "t4"

edges <- rad$texts[rad$segments %>% rownames() %>% as.integer()] %>% 
  matrix(byrow = T, ncol = 2)

g <- edges %>% igraph::graph_from_edgelist(directed = F) 

igraph::E(g)
#> + 24/24 edges from fef771a (vertex names):
#>  [1] f1--s2 f1--t1 f1--t3 f1--s4 f2--t2 f2--s1 f2--s3 f2--t4 s2--f3 t2--f3
#> [11] t1--f3 s1--f3 t3--f4 s3--f4 s4--f4 t4--f4 s2--f5 t2--f5 t3--f5 s3--f5
#> [21] t1--f6 s1--f6 s4--f6 t4--f6

nghmap <- lapply(1:6, function(k) {
  txt <- rad$texts[k]
  ngh <- igraph::neighbors(g, txt)
  vals <- names(ngh) %>% sort() %>% str_remove_all("(s|t)") %>% as.numeric()
  c(sort(vals[1:2]), sort(vals[3:4]))
}) %>% abind::abind(along = 2) %>% t() %>% `[`(TRUE,c(3,4,1,2))

nghmap
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
#> [1,]    1    3    2    4
#> [2,]    2    4    1    3
#> [3,]    1    2    1    2
#> [4,]    3    4    3    4
#> [5,]    2    3    2    3
#> [6,]    1    4    1    4

Actually, the work that was just illustrated here was already done when the rhombic dodecahedron was cunstructed.

identical(nghmap, rhombic_dodecahedron$nghmap)
#> [1] TRUE

Aligning the cube and the octahedron 

dic <- deltoidal_icositetrahedron
cu <- cube
oct <- octahedron
co <- cuboctahedron
co$texts <- str_c('o', 1:12)
dic$texts <- rep("", 26)
display_poly(dic, dual = co, 
             scale = 1.414, zoom = 0.65)

Figure 2a. A deltoidal icositetrahedron
containing a cuboctahedron 

display_poly(dic, dual = cu, codual = oct, 
             scale = 1.53, coscale = 2, zoom = 0.65)

Figure 1b. A deltoidal icositetrahedron
containing a cube and an octahedron


Aligning the rhombic dodecahedron and the cuboctahedron
